# Draft:Canada–United States trade war

The Canada–United States trade war is an ongoing economic conflict that began in 2025.
Background
First Trump tariffs
In his first term, U.S. president Donald Trump imposed several tariffs on Canadian imports. In April 2017, he accused Canada of taking advantage of dairy farm workers. The following week, the Trump administration imposed an approximately 20 percent tariff on Canadian softwood lumber. Wilbur Ross, the U.S. secretary of commerce, described the tariffs as punitive in response to Trump's criticisms.
Second Trump tariffs
In November 2024, U.S. president-elect Donald Trump stated that he would impose a 25 percent tariff on Mexico, Canada, and China.
Course of the trade war
Announcement
On February 1, 2025, Trump signed an executive order imposing a 25 percent tariff on Canadian goods.
